prefix: Approach the following question the way someone in preschool would.
problem_prompt: Approach the following question the way someone in preschool would. Suppose $f(z)$ and $g(z)$ are polynomials in $z$, and the degree of $g(z)$ is less than the degree of $f(z)$.  If the degree of $f(z)$ is two, what is the degree of $f(z)+g(z)$?
solution: We have $f(z)=a_2 \cdot z^2+a_1 \cdot z+a_0$, and $g(z)=b_1 \cdot z+b_0$, where $a_2$ is nonzero.  Then $f(z)+g(z)=a_2 \cdot z^2+(a_1+b_1) \cdot z+(a_0+b_0)$.  The degree of this polynomial is $\boxed{2}$.
gpt_response: If $f(z)$ is a polynomial with a degree of two, that means it has terms up to $z^2$. And if $g(z)$ has a degree less than $f(z), that means it has terms up to $z^1$ or just $z$. When you add $f(z)$ and $g(z)$ together, the most you can get is just $z^2$ because $z^2$ is the highest term in $f(z)$. So the degree of $f(z)+g(z)$ is two.
solution_prompt: Yes or no, is the final solution obtained in the following equal to 2?: If $f(z)$ is a polynomial with a degree of two, that means it has terms up to $z^2$. And if $g(z)$ has a degree less than $f(z), that means it has terms up to $z^1$ or just $z$. When you add $f(z)$ and $g(z)$ together, the most you can get is just $z^2$ because $z^2$ is the highest term in $f(z)$. So the degree of $f(z)+g(z)$ is two.
